Olga en todas las reuniones programadas asiste puntualmente, amortiguando cada una de cuotas señaladas de acuerdo a su cronograma de pago, este es su quinto préstamo con MFP. Con el dinero solicitado comprará mayor cantidad de madera para la fabricación de más cajones para frutas.
texts.en:
Olga , 28, has lived for 11 years with her partner and their 3 children. They live in a rented house and devote their time to manufacturing fruit crates, work they have been doing for more than 11 years. This work gives them much joy and economic satisfaction, since despite the tough competition, Olga loves her work. She cuts and shapes the wood, measuring to the appropriate thickness, to fabricate crates for bananas, avocados, and other produce. They produce from 200 to 400 crates per month, investing from 100 to 200 soles, and making a profit double the initial investment. They prepare their shipments weekly, which means that often they begin work at 4 in the morning and work until 10 at night. Since the orders are increasing, they must look for a person to help them, in order to take advantage of these months, since the rest of the year sales are not as good, due to the seasonal nature of agricultural products. Olga attends every program meeting punctually, acquitting every fee in accordance with her payment schedule--this is her fifth loan through MFP. With the money she is requesting, she will buy a larger quantity of wood for the fabrication of additional fruit crates.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of materials for fruit crates

loans.name: Erminia

texts.es:
La señora Erminia V. A. tiene 47 años, vive en el sector Gran Chimu del distrito El Porvenir, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Estudio hasta 3ro de primaria, dejó los estudios debido a que su padre se enfermó y tuvieron que trabajar para salir adelante, tiene una pequeña hija que depende enteramente de ella.
Erminia se dedica a la venta de ropa de dormitorio y quesillo, se inicio con la venta de accesorios de carro, negocio que le fue muy rentable hasta que perdió todo su capital cuando le decomisaron su mercadería. Viajo a Argentina por un tiempo y al regresar empezó vendiendo menú, el mismo que abandono debido a que se enfermó; luego se inició en la venta de carne, quesillo y ropa de dormitorio, negocio que aun desarrolla en su propia casa.
Con el primer crédito de 300 soles que recibió de su Banco Comunal “Mujeres  del Milenium”, lo invirtió en la compra de una cocina semindustrial.
Con este crédito de 1000 soles, que será cancelado en 4 meses, lo invertirá en la compra de  ropa para dormitorio. 
Erminia sueña con abrir una tienda de accesorios para carros.
texts.en:
Ms. Erminia V. A. is a 47-year-old woman who lives in Gran Chimu, district of Porvenir, in the Trujillo province of the department La Libertad, Peru. She completed three years of grade school, but then stopped studying because her father got sick and they had to work in order to get ahead. She has one dependent young daughter. Erminia sells bedclothes and cheese for a living. She began by selling car accessories, which was a very profitable business until she lost all her capital when her merchandise was confiscated. She then went to Argentina for a while and when she returned began selling menu meals. She had to abandon this business because she got sick. She then began selling meat, cheese, and bedclothes from her home. A business she is still in the process of developing. She invested the first 300.00 loan she received from her local bank “Mujeres del Milenium” in the purchase of a semi-industrial kitchen. She will invest this 1000.00 loan, which will be repaid in 4 months, in the purchase of bedclothes. Erminia’s dream is to open a car accessories store.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invertir en la compra de ropa para dormitorio, negocio que tiene en su casa.

loans.name: Flor Consuelo

texts.es:
La señora Flor Consuelo Y. D. T. tiene 74 años, vive en la Urb. Santo Dominguito, distrito D. Trujillo, provincia D. Trujillo, departamento D. La Libertad, Perú.
Ella estudio hasta 4to D. primaria, dejó los estudios para que sus hermanos pequeños puedan estudiar y se dedicó a trabajar. Tiene 05 hijos y ninguno depenD. económicamente D. ella.
Flor se dedica a la venta D. leña y briqueta, al comienzo vendía menú y sus clientes la incentivaron para que venda briqueta y leña, empezó vendiendo leña y briqueta en poca cantidad en un mercado, con el tiempo se hizo conocida y D. muchos clientes, ahora su negocio es granD. y muy rentable. Su negocio lo desarrolla en su propio domicilio.
Con el primer crédito D. 300 soles que recibió D. su Banco Comunal “Mujeres  del Milenium”, lo invirtió en la compra D. briquetas.
Con este crédito D. 3000 soles, que será cancelado en 4 meses, lo invertirá en la compra D. leña y briqueta.
Flor sueña con comprarse un carro.
texts.en:
Flor Consuelo Y. D. T. is 74 years old. She lives in the town of Santo Dominguito, in the Trujillo district of Trujillo province in La Libertad, Peru. She attended school until fourth graD., then dropped out and began to work so that her younger siblings could go to school. She has five children, who are all financially independent. Flor sells firewood and charcoal. She started out selling pre-cooked meals, but her customers requested that she sell charcoal and firewood. She began to sell firewood and charcoal in small quantities in a market, and over time she became well-known and gained many clients. Now her business is large and very profitable. She runs her business out of her home. With her first loan of 300 soles that she received from the Communal Bank "Women of the Millennium," she invested in the purchase of charcoal. With this loan of 3000 soles, which she will repay in four months, she will invest in the purchase of firewood and charcoal. Flor dreams of buying herself a car.

Translated from Spanish by Leah Karlins, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase firewood and charcoal for her business

loans.name: Julia

texts.es:
La señora Julia C. M. tiene 56 años, vive en el sector Víctor Raúl del distrito El Porvenir, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Estudio secundaria completa y algunos cursos de costura, tiene 02 hijos de los cuales 01 depende económicamente de ella. 
Julia se dedica a la costura y a la venta de leña y briqueta, se inicio en el negocio cosiendo en una pequeña maquina, con las ganancias que obtuvo adquirió una máquina de coser moderna y una remalladora, al tiempo empezó la venta de briqueta y leña que fue creciendo poco a poco, así también la venta de productos de belleza. Su negocio lo desarrolla en su propia casa. 
Con el primer crédito de 300 soles que recibió de su Banco Comunal “Mujeres  del Milenium”, lo invirtió en la compra de mercería para su negocio.
Con este crédito de 500 soles, que será cancelado en 4 meses, lo invertirá en la compra de leña y briquetas.
Julia tiene el sueño de terminar de construir su casa y tener un taller de costura.
texts.en:
Julia C. M. is 56 years old . She lives in the Víctor Raúl sector of the El Porvenir district, in the province of Trujillo, in La Libertad, Perú. She is a high school graduate and has taken some sewing courses. She has two children, one of whom is financially dependent on her. Julia works as a seamstress and also sells firewood and charcoal. She began her business sewing on a small sewing machine, and with her earnings she purchased a modern sewing machine and an overlocker machine. She began to sell charcoal and firewood, and her sales gradually expanded, as did her sale of beauty products. She runs her business out of her home. With the first loan of 300 soles that she received from the Communal Bank, "Women of the Millennium," she invested in the purchases of wares for her business. With this loan of 500 soles, which she will repay in four months, she will invest in the purchase of firewood and charcoal. Julia's ambition is to finish the construction of her house and have her own seamstress shop.

Translated from Spanish by Leah Karlins, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase firewood and charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Julia

texts.es:
La señora Julia S. C. tiene 49 años, vive en el sector Víctor Raúl del distrito El Porvenir, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Estudió hasta 3ro de primaria, dejó los estudios debido a que sus padres no la quisieron apoyar y se dedicó a trabajar, tiene 4 hijos de los cuales ninguno depende económicamente de ella.
Julia tiene un carro el cual trabaja como colectivo, cuando ella se inicio en el negocio vendía plásticos en los mercados, luego empezó la venta de zapatos que enviaba al norte del país, con las ganancias que obtuvo compro su carro con el cual trabaja desde hace 3 años. Su negocio se desarrolla en la ruta porvenir – centro de Trujillo. 
Con el primer crédito de 300 soles que recibió de su Banco Comunal “Mujeres  del Milenium”, lo invirtió en la compra de plásticos.
Con este crédito de 500 soles, que será cancelado en 4 meses, lo invertirá en la compra de llantas para su carro. 
Julia sueña con terminar de construir su casa y comprarse otro carro moderno.
texts.en:
Julia S. C. is 49 years old. She lives in the town of Víctor Raúl, in the El Porvenir district, in Trujillo province, in La Libertad, Perú. She has a third-grade education. She had to leave school and start working because her parents did not want to support her. She has four children who are now financially independent. Julia has a car that she uses to run a taxi service. When she started her business, she sold plastic wares in markets. Then she began to sell shoes, sending them to the north of the country. With her earnings, she bought her car which she has driven as a taxi for three years. She works along Route Porvenir, in the center of Trujillo. With her first loan of 300 soles that she received from the Communal Bank, "Women of the Millennium," she invested in the purchase of plastic wares. With this loan of 500, which she will repay in four months, she will purchase new tires for her car. Julia dreams of finishing the construction of her house and buying a more modern car.

Translated from Spanish by Leah Karlins, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchases new tires for her taxi

loans.name: Vanessa

texts.es: Vanessa tiene 20 años de edad, vive cerca de 5 años con su pareja y tienen un hijo, viven en una casa alquilada donde realizan sus negocio de venta de golosinas y gaseosas. Ella anteriormente cultivaba el campo con su esposo; pero como la chacra no es tan rentable en ciertas épocas, abrió una tienda de golosinas y venta de gaseosas hace 8 meses, resultándole muy rentable. En el primer préstamo que obtuvo con MFP logró comprar un estante, pero ahora con este préstamo quiere implementar su bodega, con más productos. A Vanessa le agrada estar en contacto con la gente, y de paso va generando ingresos a su economía, mientras que su esposo se dedica a cultivar sus chacras frutales, que en ciertas  temporadas producen frutos en cantidades, lo que lo alientan a seguir sembrando. El anhelo de Vanessa es tener un terreno propio para que se evite pagar el derecho de alquiler del inmueble donde tiene su tienda. Ingresó a su banco comunal en el tercer ciclo y en todo este tiempo ha demostrado pagar puntualmente sus cuotas, este es su segundo préstamo con MFP, institución con la cual siente una gran identificación. El dinero que solicita es para incrementar los productos de su tienda de golosinas y de ese modo sea mucha más surtida y capte mayor clientela.
texts.en:
Vanessa is 20 years old and has been living with her partner close to 5 years and they have a son. They live in a house they've rented and where they run their business selling snacks and soft drinks. Previously she cultivated a field with her husband; but produce isn't that profitable in certain seasons, so she opened a store to sell snacks and soft drinks 8 months ago, and finding it very profitable. In the first loan she received from MFP (Kiva Field Partner) she managed to purchase a stand, but now with this loan she wants to stock her store with more products. Vanessa loves to be in contact with people, and in doing so she is generating an income for herself, and meanwhile her husband dedicates his time to cultivate fruit that in certain seasons they produce fruit in great quantities, something they hope to keep harvesting. Vanessa's goal is to have her own fields to no longer have to pay rent on the building where she has her store. She sought the community bank in her third loan cycle and her history indicates that she makes payments on time, on this her second loan from MFP, an institution of which she feels part. The funds requested will be used to stock her snack store to increase selection, to the end of increasing her client base.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase her merchandise.

loans.name: María Alicia

texts.es:
La señora María Alicia U. M. tiene 36 años, vive en el sector Víctor Raúl del distrito El Porvenir, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Estudio hasta 2do de secundaria, abandonó los estudios debido a que sus padres no la quisieron apoyar y se dedicó al negocio, tiene 03 hijos que dependen enteramente de ella. 
María tiene una bodega, se inicio en el negocio vendiendo en la puerta de su casa frutas, galletas y mazamorra, poco a poco fue implementando su bodega con abarrotes, gaseosas y ahora cuenta con una bodega surtida, también compro una mesita de fulbito. Su negocio lo desarrolla en su propia casa.
Con el primer crédito de 300 soles que recibió de su Banco Comunal “Mujeres  del Milenium”, lo invirtió en la compra de una mesa de fulbito.
Con este crédito de 400 soles, que será cancelado en 4 meses, lo invertirá en la compra de abarrotes para su bodega.
Maria sueña con tener su casa propia.
texts.en:
María Alicia U. M. is 36 years old and resides in Víctor Raúl, in the county of El Porvenir, in Trujillo province, in La Libertad, Perú. She completed her education through the second year of secondary school. Then she left school because her parents did not want to support her, and and went into business. She has three children who depend entirely on her for support. Maria has a small grocery store. She began her business by selling fruits, cookies, and crackers from her front door. Gradually, she turned into a real grocery store by adding various snacks, carbonated beverages, and now she even has a stocked wine cellar. She also bought a foosball table. She runs her store out of her own home. With her first loan of 300 soles from the Communal Bank "Women of the Millennium," she purchased the foosball table. With this loan of 400 soles, which she will repay in four months, she will purchase groceries for her shop. Maria dreams of owning her own home.

Translated from Spanish by Leah Karlins, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase groceries for her shop

loans.name: María Del Pilar

texts.es:
La señora María del Pilar Ruiz D. tiene 25 años, vive en el distrito de Paijan,  provincia de Ascope, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Estudio Secretariado Ejecutivo, carrera que no ejerció debido a que los sueldos no cubrían sus expectativas, tiene 02 hijos que dependen económicamente  de ella.
María se dedica a la venta de regalos y adornos, se inicio vendiendo ropa interior y regalos, con el tiempo fue abandonando la venta de ropa y dedicándose solo a la venta de regalos y sandalias por campaña de verano negocio que le es muy rentable el mismo que lo desarrolla en su propio domicilio.
 Con el primer crédito de 300 soles que recibió de su Banco Comunal “Honestidad y Confianza”, lo invirtió en la compra de mercadería para aumentar su capital.
Con el crédito de 800 soles, que será cancelado en 4 meses, lo invertirá en la compra de  sandalias para campaña de verano.
María sueña con tener un stand donde pueda vender mecería, bijouteri y ropa.
texts.en:
Maria del Pilar Ruiz Diaz is 25 years old and lives in the district of Paijan, province of Ascope, department of La Libertad, Peru. She studied to be an executive secretary but did not practice her career because the salary would not have covered her expenses as she has two children that economically depend on her. Maria dedicates herself to the sale of gifts and decorations. She started off selling undergarments and gifts and in time she stopped selling clothes and dedicated herself to selling only gifts and sandals during the summer. She carries out this business from her home and the business is very profitable. Maria invested the first loan that she received in the amount of 300 soles from the communal bank "Honestidad y Confianza" in purchasing merchandise in order to increase her capital. This loan which she is requesting in the amount of 800 soles and which she will repay in four months will be invested in purchasing sandals for the summer. Maria dreams of having a stand where she can sell her merchandise, costume jewelry and clothing.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Manzo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase sandals to sell during the summer season.

loans.name: Mery Elizabeth

texts.es:
La señora Mery Elizabeth T. Y. tiene 43 años, vive en la Urb. Santo Dominguito, distrito de Trujillo, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Ella estudio Técnica en Laboratorio Clínico, carrera que ejerció durante 2 años y abandono debido a que se caso y se dedico a su hogar. Tiene 03 hijos que dependen de ella económicamente. 
Mery se dedica a la venta de coronas, útiles escolares y abarrotes al por mayor, se inicio con la venta de coronas que envía a la sierra al mismo tiempo que trabajo en un pronoi por 17 años, luego empezó a vender roscas, manjar blanco y quesos, asimismo  la venta de  útiles escolares, abarrotes y manualidades.
Con el primer crédito de 300 soles que recibió de su Banco Comunal “Mujeres  del Milenium”, lo invirtió en la compra de telas para elaborar sus coronas.
Con el crédito de 2000 soles, que será cancelado en 4 meses, lo invertirá en la compra de  azúcar para distribuir a las bodegas.
Mery tiene el sueño de construir su casa y comprarse un carro.
texts.en:
Mery Elizabeth T. Y. is 43 years old and lives in Trujillo districto in La Libertad, Peru. She studied to be technician in a clinical laboratory, a career that she had for two years. She left her job when she got married to take care of her home. She has three children that depend on her financially. Mery sells wreaths, school supplies, and groceries in wholesale prices. She began the business with the sale of wreaths which she sent to the mountains. At the same time, she worked in Pronoi (an education center) for 17 years. Later, she began to sell roscas (a type of ring-shaped cake or bread roll), dulce de leche, and cheese, as well as school supplies, groceries, and handicrafts. With the first loan of 300 soles she received from the communal bank "Mujeres del Milenium" (Millenium Women), she invested in the purchase of fabric to decorate her wreaths. With this loan of 2000 soles to be repaid four months, she will invest in the purchase of sugar to distribute to the grocery stores. Mery dreams of building her house and buying a car.

Translated from Spanish by Annie Sheng, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sugar to distribute in grocery stores at wholesale prices

loans.name: Rosa Nelly

texts.es:
La señora Rosa Nelly D. P. tiene 45 años, vive en el distrito de Paijan,  provincia de Ascope, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Estudio secundaria completa, además de cursos de costura, tiene un hijo que ya no depende económicamente de ella.
Rosa se dedica a la confección de ropa, inicio su negocio hace ya 15 años con una pequeña máquina de coser, poco a poco se fue haciendo conocida y de clientela, con el tiempo fue ampliando su negocio con la compra de telas  que les vende a sus clientes y mercería que utiliza en la confección, su negocio se desarrolla en su domicilio.
 Con el primer crédito de 300 soles que recibió de su Banco Comunal “Honestidad y Confianza”, lo invirtió en la compra de mercería y telas.
Con este crédito de 250 soles, que será cancelado en 4 meses, lo invertirá en la compra de  telas de verano y mercería. 
Rosa tiene el sueño de comprarse una máquina de coser moderna.
texts.en:
Rosa Nelly D. P. is 45 years old and lives in Paijan district in Ascope province, in La Libertad, Peru. She finished secondary school, in addition to classes in sewing. She has a son who no longer depends on her financially. Rosa makes clothing. She began her business 15 years ago with a small sewing machine, and little by little she became more widely known by her customers. With time, she expanded her business by purchasing fabric that she sells to her customers and hardware she uses for making clothes. She runs her business from her home. With her first loan of 300 soles that she received from her communal bank "Honestidad y Confianza" (Honesty and Reliability), she invested in the purchase of hardware and fabric. With this loan of 250 soles to be repaid in 4 months, she will invest in the purchase of summer fabric and hardware. Rosa dreams of buying a modern sewing machine.

Translated from Spanish by Annie Sheng, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy summer fabric and hardware

loans.name: Sandra Zulianita

texts.es:
La señora Sandra Zulianita Z. R. tiene 27 años es presidenta de su Banco Comunal, vive en el distrito de El Porvenir, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Estudio Secretariado Ejecutivo, carrera que ejerció durante 6 años la misma que decidió abandonar debido a que los sueldos no cubrían sus expectativas y se animo a abrir su negocio, a la vez que salio embarazada, tiene 01 hijo pequeño que depende enteramente de ella.
Sandra tiene un Internet en sociedad con su padre, se inicio en el negocio con la venta de material dental junto con su hermana durante 4 años, con las ganancias que obtuvo decidió abrir un Internet negocio que hasta ahora desarrolla en su domicilio.
Con el primer crédito de 300 soles que recibió de su Banco Comunal “Mujeres  del Milenium”, lo invirtió en la compra de  material dental.
Con este crédito de 250 soles, que será cancelado en 4 meses, lo invertirá en el mantenimiento de sus equipos de cómputo.
Sandra tiene el gran sueño de viajar por todo el Perú y de comprarse una casa.
texts.en:
Sandra Zulianita Z. R. is 27 years old and is president of her Banco Comunal (communal bank). She lives in El Porvenir district, in Trujillo, La Libertad. She studied to be an executive secretariat. She worked as an executive secretariat for six years, before she decided to abandon it since her salary didn't meet her expectations and she was interested in opening her own business. At that time, she became pregnant and had a child that depended entirely on her. Sandra has an internet cafe company with her father. He started with selling dental material with his daughter for four years. With the earnings they obtained, they decided to open an internet cafe business from their home, which they currently run now. With the first loan of 300 soles that she received from Banco Comunal "Mujeres de Milenium" (Communal Bank, "Women of the Millenium"), she invested in the purchase of dental material. With this current loan of 250 soles that she will return in 4 months, she will invest in the maintenance of the computer equipment. Sandra has a grand dream of traveling all over Peru and buying a house.

Translated from Spanish by Annie Sheng, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in the maintenance of computer equipment

loans.name: Santos Elena

texts.es:
La señora Santos Elena A. M. tiene 46 años, vive en el sector Víctor Raúl del distrito El Porvenir, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Estudio secundaria completa, además de algunos cursos de costura, tiene 03 hijos de los cuales 02 aun dependen de ella económicamente.
Santos Elena se dedica a la venta de fruta y flores, al comienzo criaba animales menores para la venta negocio que aun mantiene, por un tiempo se dedico a la venta de calzado y luego se inicio también en la venta de fruta con las ganancias que obtuvo amplio su negocio a la venta de flores el mismo que desarrolla en el mercado Los Portales de la Urb. Huerta Bella. 
Con el primer crédito de 300 soles que recibió de su Banco Comunal “Mujeres  del Milenium”, lo invirtió en la compra de alimento balanceado para sus animales.
Con el crédito de 1800 soles, que será cancelado en 4 meses, lo invertirá en la compra de  alimento balanceado y flores para su negocio. 
Santos Elena sueña con adquirir un puesto propio en el mercado y lograr que sus hijos sean profesionales.
texts.en:
Santos Elena A. M. is 46 years old and lives in the Víctor Raúl sector of El Porvenir district, Trujillo district, department of La Libertad, Peru. She finished high school and also took some sewing courses. She has three children, two of which are financially dependent on her.

Santos Elena sells fruit and flowers. At first she raised small animals for sale, a business she still maintains. For a while she sold shoes, and then she got started in the sale of fruit as well. With the profits she earned, she expanded her business to selling flowers in the Los Portales de la Urb. Huerta Bella market.

With the first loan of 300 soles that she received from her communal bank "Mujeres del Milenium" [women of the millenium], she invested in the purchase of nutritional animal feed.

With the 1800 soles loan, which will be paid off in four months, she will invest in the purchase of nutritional animal feed and flowers for her business.

Santos Elena dreams of buying her own stall in the market and that her children will manage to have professional careers.

Translated from Spanish by Heidi Petersen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Will invest in the purchase of nutritional animal feed and flowers for her business.

loans.name: Marcos

texts.es:
El señor Marcos L. tiene ya más de 12 años con su taller de herrero, el cual elabora, (puertas y ventanas), esté negocio es la fuente de ingresos de su familia. En esté momento le está haciendo falta material  para poder realizar los pedido que tiene, pero no cuenta con el capital necesario. Es por eso que solicita un préstamo para poder comprar el material y así  realizar los pedidos y entregarlos a tiempo. Para que sus clientes estén más satisfechos con su trabajo y lo puedan recomendar con otras personas, y así su negocio crezca más. 
Don Marcos planea pagar el crédito con las ganancias de su negocio.
texts.en:
Marcos L. has had his blacksmith's shop where he makes doors and windows for 12 years. This business is the source of income for his family. At this moment he is lacking materials to fill the orders he has but he does not have the necessary capital to purchase them. This is why he is asking for a loan to purchase materials and be able to fill his orders deliver them on time so that his clients can be satisfied with his work and recommend him to other people. Marcos plans on paying this loan with the profits from his business.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Manzo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase materials to make doors and windows.

loans.name: Ernesto

texts.en:
Ernesto C. is a 41-year-old farmer. He grows rice to support his family's daily needs. His wife helps him take care of their 2 children; one child is in college while the other is still in high school. He came from a family of farmers and through farming he is able to build the future of his children. 

He started cultivating their small parcel of land in 1995. His harvest is intended for family consumption and the remainder is sold to rice traders in their village. He is asking for a loan of Php 12,000 ($275 USD) from CEVI. He will use the loan to purchase 1 bag of rice seed, 4 bags of urea, 3 bags of Triple 14 fertilizers, and payments for his laborer.

CEVI is helping Ernesto sustain his farm. Now, as a CEVI client, he enjoys the credit assistance, training, savings, and insurance services that they give to all their members.

loans.use: To purchase rice seeds and fertilizers, and to rent a tractor and a weeder

loans.name: Nasanjargal

texts.en:
Nasanjargal J. is a married woman who lives with her husband and two children. Both her children go to school. She runs a wholesale stall at the Narantuul market in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Narantuul is the largest outdoor market in Mongolia -- it runs year-round despite winter temperatures far below freezing. Her husband helps her to buy her stock.

Since they've run a wholesale business for the last eight years, they've acquired a lot of experience and their business capital has increased to MNT 8 million (about USD 5,000). Average daily gross income from sales is MNT 400,000-500,000 (250-320 USD). She sells all sorts of items wholesale, from tea to soap to biscuits. She controls the family finances, and she is actively saving money in a fund for her children's future university tuition. Her goal is to one day own her own big wholesale store.

loans.use: To buy several types of wholesale items: tea, soap, biscuits, etc.

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en:
“ I always wanted the best life for my children”, says Maribel Tasara, a pig grower from Surallah South Cotabato. She is 29 years old and has two children who are in elementary school. Her husband is a farmer. Every day, her husband goes out to the farm, touching the dirt, feeling the heat of the sun to have food for the family. Together, they work very hard to meet the needs of their children. 

She is asking for a loan of Php 10,000 ($225 USD) from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy feed for her pigs. Specifically, the loan will be used to purchase 5 sacks of starter, grower and finisher. She is also looking for some other possible income areas to support her family.

CEVI is helping Maribel grow her business. She has access to CEVI credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage by joining the program.

loans.use: To buy feed for the pigs.

loans.name: Marisssa

texts.en:
Marissa G. raises pigs in her backyard. She is 35 years old and has two children. Her husband works as a driver and his income is not enough to support their family. Her children are studying and she is worrying about where to get the money to pay for their tuition fees and other school projects. The income that she earns from raising pigs is a big help to their family.

Now, she is asking for a loan of Php 12,000 ($275 USD) from CEVI to purchase feed for her pigs. She will also use the loan to buy piglets. In this way, she believes, she can earn more for her children's education.

CEVI provides their clients the credit assistance they need. They also provide training, savings services, and insurance coverage to all their clients.

loans.use: To buy feed for the pigs.

loans.name: Adyamaa

texts.en:
Adyamaa Y. has been taking loans from XacBank, Kiva's partner micro-finance institution in Mongolia, for four years. She is married with three children. To help her husband to feed the children, she engages in retail business at the "Narantuul" market, the biggest Mongolian outdoor market, which operates in all four seasons. In the winter, it's very challenging to operate her business as temperatures routinely fall below -20 degrees Celsius.

Adyamaa's business is selling used clothes. She buys used clothes by the kilogram, imported from South Korea. A couple of years ago, she leased a car through XacBank for use in her business. From the previous loan profit, she fixed her house, a traditional Mongolian "ger" (form of nomadic housing). Adyamaa is a hard-working person. She plans to use her Kiva loan to buy more clothing to sell.

loans.use: To buy used clothes to increase her business inventory

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
Nida T. is engaged in rice farming. She grows and sells rice to help her 8 married children. She is 50 years old  and the only thing that she worries about is the future of her children because they all married so early. She still helps her children sustain their new families. Her harvest is used for the family's consumption and the remainder is  sold in the market for additional income. She started her farm business in 1980 on 1 ½ hectares of  land. Now her farm is growing and established.

She is requesting a loan of Php 12,000 to increase her harvest. In this way, she believes, she will have more profit to share with her married children. Her loan will be used to buy herbicides and fertilizers needed for her farm.

CEVI provides their clients not just with a loan but also with training, savings services and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To buy herbicides and fertilizer for her farm.

loans.name: Keng

texts.en: Keng A. is 64 years old and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham province. She and her husband have worked together selling bricks and construction tools since 2003 to earn a living. They make around US$ 10 every day. This couple has two children and both are married and live away from home. Mrs. Keng A. is asking for a loan to purchase more bricks and expand her construction tools inventory to meet her customers’ demand.

loans.use: Construction materials for re-sale

loans.name: Bella

texts.en:
Bella T. is a pig grower. She raises pigs because she enjoys the work. Aside from that, she thinks that raising pigs is a profitable business. Because of her pigs, she has money to spend for her daily needs.  She is 52 years old. Three of her 6 children are already married and the others are still studying. Her husband, a farmer, is the one who manages their small parcel of land. Bella wants to help her husband so she raises pigs to contribute to the family income.

She is asking for a CEVI loan of Php 10,000. She will use the loan to buy feed for her pigs. Specifically, the money will go to pay for 3 sacks of starter, grower and finisher mash. In this way, she will have healthier jumbo pigs to sell in the market.

CEVI sustains their clients' businesses. They give their clients credit assistance, training and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To purchase feed for her pigs

loans.name: Bat-Ulzii

texts.en:
B. Bat-ulzii has been taking loans from XacBank, Kiva's partner micro-finance institution in Mongolia, for three years. He is a married man who runs the family retail business with his spouse at the Narantuul market (an enormous outdoor market in the capital city, Ulaanbaatar).

B. and his wife work year-round in the market despite temperatures that dive below -20 Celsius for months and months during the winter. B. moved from Arhangai to Ulaanbaatar with his wife and four children in 2000. Since he began to live in Ulaanbaatar, he makes horse saddles at home and sells them in the market. They buy wood from the Arhangai province for the saddles (at a big discount), which he sculpts, and his wife sews the top part of the saddle.

They are trying to grow their children healthy and educated. That is why they are working hard. In the picture B. is standing on the right side, and his wife on the left. The loan they are requesting is to buy more raw materials -- wood and cotton -- to make new saddles.

loans.use: To buy wood and cotton for saddle-making

loans.name: Visitacion

texts.en:
Visitacion C. has been growing rice since 1985. For almost 23 years, she has spent her whole life on the farm. She tills the soil, feels the heat of the sun, plants the rice seedlings and waits for the good harvest to come. She is 54 years old and has three children; one in college and two still in high school. She is already a widow. Her husband died from an illness. Now she is the only one who manages the farm. Her children help her on the farm during their free time.

She is requesting a loan from CEVI. She will use the loan to purchase fertilizer for her farm. She believes that her loan will bring her a good harvest. The fertilizer will allow her farm to produce a good yield. She is also willing to look for some other income-generating activities. In this way, she could support fully the needs of her children.

CEVI helps Visitacion with her farm. She has access to the credit assistance, training and insurance coverage that CEVI gives to all its clients.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her farm

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita C. grows pigs in her backyard. She has been raising pigs since 2004, using her own little savings. She started her business with two piglets. Up until now, she grows pigs because she enjoys the work and is able to earn a profit from this kind of endeavor. She is 53 years old. Two of her eight children are still in college. She needs more income to support their studies.


She is asking for a loan from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy feed for the pigs. Specifically, the loan will go to pay for two sacks of starter feed, three sacks of hog grower feed and four sacks of hog finisher feed. With her loan, she is assured that she will have bigger pigs to sell and will have additional income for her family. She is also looking into some other possible income areas to support her family. CEVI provides everyone a chance to change his or her life. Through the credit assistance, training and insurance coverage that they give, many are able to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To buy feed for the pigs

loans.name: Mrs. Pheap Uy Village Bank Group

texts.en:
10 people living in Damnak Key village in Kampong Chhnang province comprise this village bank loan and will use the loan for a variety of purposes. Mrs. Pheap U., the 44 year-old village bank president, is a basket maker. Her husband, Mr. Leang Doeurn, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Even though they have different careers, they still earn less income to provide a better house for their family. Thus, Mrs. Pheap U. has decided to ask for a loan to to build a new house. She has six children, one of whom is employed at a garment factory while another is a construction worker and the others are enrolled in the local school. 

Eight members in this group loans are end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To to build the new house for her family

loans.name: Mrs. Pheun Khoem Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank consists of eight members and is located in Trapang Kor village in Kampong Chhnang province. They plan to use the loan which they obtained for different purposes. Mrs. PheU. K. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a seller a mall restaurant that sells rice soup. Her husband, Mr. Noup Suth, is a musician who has been hired by the people to perform at wedding ceremonies, parties, and others events. Even though they try to work hard, they still earn too little income to build a new house for their family. Thus, Mrs. PheU. K. has decided to ask for a loan so that she can build a house for her family. She is a 54-year-old mother of three children, two of whom are employed in garment factory while the other helps the mother’s business.

Two members in this group loans are end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To build a house for her family.

loans.name: Sotheavy's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sotheavy S. is a group leader of five members who all live in the Kampong Boeng village in Kampong Chhnang province. She is a pig breeder. Since her breeding pigs business is doing well, she wishes to expand it by purchasing more piglets for breeding. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family living conditions with this loan. Mrs. Sotheavy S. is 26 years old and is a mother of three children, one of whom is attending the local school while the others are too young to work or study. Her husband, Mr. Chhin Teth, is a motorbiK. repairer. 

One member in this group loans is end-of-term loan and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to maK. payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients maK. their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more piglets for her breeding pig business.

loans.name: Ry's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Ry N. is a group leader of six members who all live in Tang Kruos Lech village in Kampong Chhnang province. She is a firewood seller. Her husband, Mr. Vean Ta, is a rice miller. Aside from this career, he is a farmer who owns a plot of land that he uses to cultivate rice. On this plantation, he gets a little income to support his household. In order to improve the family living, Mrs. Ry N. has decided to ask for a loan so that she can buy a piece of land to cultivate rice to increase her revenue. She is 45 years old and the mother of four children, who are all enrolled in the local school.

loans.use: To buy a piece of land to cultivate rice in order to increase her rice revenue.

loans.name: Phea's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Phea M. is a group leader of five who all live in Tropeang Srongae village in Kampong Chhnang province. She is a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. Vorn Vy, is a musician who has been hired by the people to perform at wedding ceremonies, parties, and others events. Mrs. Phea M. is applying to a loan so that she can buy pigs and start a new business. She is 27 years old and the mother of two children who are attending the local school. 

Three members in this group loans are end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy pigs to start new pig breeding business to earn more income

loans.name: Srey Mom's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Srey Mom C. is a group leader of four of whom all live in Phum Ty 8 village in Kampong Chhnang province. She is a vegetable seller in the local market. Since her business is doing well, she wishes to expand it by purchasing more vegetables to resell and thereby, earn more profits. Her husband, Mr. Un Pao, is a laborer. Mrs. Srey Mom C. is 22 years old and the mother of two children who are too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy vegetables to resell to earn more profits.

loans.name: Mrs. Mao Prum Village Bank Group

texts.en:
14 people living in Phum Ty 8 village in Kampong Chhnang province and comprise this village bank loan. They hope to use the loan for a variety of purposes. 

Mrs. Mao P. is a 37 year-old village bank president. She breeds chickens and pigs for a living. Since her business is doing well, she wishes to expand it. Thus, she has decided to request a loan that will allow her to buy more chickens and piglets for breeding. Her husband, Mr. Keo Mono, is a farmer who owns a plot of land of which he uses to cultivate rice. Aside from this plantation, he is a laborer. Mrs. Mao P. has three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while another is attending the local school and the remaining is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy more chickens and piglets to breed and thereby earn more income.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Eng

texts.en:
Eng N. is 23 years old and lives with her child in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. 
Since 2000, she has worked as a construction worker building houses, earning about US$2 of profit per day. Her husband makes US$4 a day working as a construction foreman. 
This couple needs a loan to purchase a motorbike for commuting to work. This will help them to reduce their transportation costs.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Mr. Tang Pao Village Bank Group

texts.en:
14 people living in Trapang Kda village in Kampong Chhnang province and comprise this village bank loan. They will use the loan for a variety of purposes. 

Mr. Tang P. is a 31 year-old village bank president. He is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. His wife, Mrs. Sorn Sory, is a firewood seller. Even though they work hard, they still do not earn enough income to support their household. In order to improve their living conditions, Mr. Tang P. has decided to ask for a loan so that he may purchase a piglet to start a breeding pigs business. He is the father of three children, two of whom are enrolled in the local schoO. while the youngest one is too young to work or study. 

12 members in this group loans are end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase a piglet to start a breeding pigs business.

loans.name: Rano

texts.en:
S. Rano is 44 years old. She is married and has four children. Rano has been running a grocery store for the past 2 years. She sells sweets, preserved food, juices, soft drinks and also detergents. The goods she has for sale are of very good quality with a wide selection. Rano is respectful and patient with all of her customers which attracts people and brings them back to buy groceries from her again. Rano is seeking to keep her business sustainable and has requested a loan of $ 600 USD for the term of 9 months to increase the inventory she has for sale. We believe this current loan will enhance the potential of her business and help Rano reach all of her aspirations.    


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, and as a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th century BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet and New Western culture and Central Asian traditions. 
But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing the goods to increase the range available to clients.

loans.name: Soy

texts.en:
Soy N., 40, works as a construction worker building houses in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. 
She typically makes about US$2 every day. Her husband makes US$4 by working as a construction foreman in Phnom Penh. This couple has one child who is attending school. 
Mrs. Soy N. is asking a loan to purchase a motorbike for commuting to work. This will help reduce her transportation costs.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to reduce transportation costs.

loans.name: Vanna

texts.en: Mrs. Vanna U. is a villager in Thlork Roling village in Kampong Chhnang province. She owns a small store and sells coffee. She is a 42 year-old widow with a child who helps the mother business. Mrs. Vanna U. is applying to a loan so that she can buy a printer for her business. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family living conditions with this loan.

loans.use: To buy a printer for her business

loans.name: Chheangheng

texts.en:
Mr. Chheangheng P., 41, just married in 2008, but his wife, Mrs. Yeun Cheng, 38, has five children with her first husband. Her first son has full time employment in Phnom Penh and other children are in school. The family lives along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penn, the capital city of Cambodia. 

Chheangheng has been a house builder for sixteen years, a skill he learned from his neighbor. His wife has been selling flowers and bananas for twenty years, but she has now stopped for a while because she is pregnant. Chheangheng is requesting a loan of $500 purchase a motorbike for his son to drive to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for his son to drive to work.

loans.name: Phalla

texts.en: Mrs. Phalla N. is a villager in Thlork Roling village in Kampong Chhnang province. She is a beautician who has been hired by the people to work at wedding ceremonies, parties, and others events. Since her career is doing well, she wishes to expand it by purchasing more cosmetic supplies for her business. Her husband, Mr. Phorn Pech, is a policeman. Mrs. Phalla N. is 34 years old and the mother of three children, two of whom are attending the local school while the youngest one is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy additional cosmetic supplies for her beautician business.

loans.name: Tout

texts.en:
Tout S. is 27 years old and lives in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. 
She grows and sells various kinds of vegetables at the market, earning around US$2 per day. She has been in business for five years. Her husband catches fish in the lake and sells his catch in the market to earn approximately US$3 of profit per day. 
They have three children, two of whom are in school. 
Mrs. Tout S. would like to take out a loan to purchase a water pump. This pump will help her to irrigate her fields from the lake in case of difficulty due to climatic variability.

loans.use: To purchase a water pump.

loans.name: Berdimurod

texts.en:
Berdimurod T. has always been a hard-working man, who has made sure, from his young age, that his family never goes without their daily bread. He is married and has two children. Berdimurod has a general store where he sells different kinds of foodstuffs, etc.. With a starting capital of 500 USD, thanks to perseverance and dedication, he began this enterprise 8 years ago. 

Over time, he expanded his business and today this has  become a family business and his daughter and son are also engaged in this business. Today he needs to buy additional foodstuffs to increase the range of his goods. With this purpose in mind,  he is requesting a loan of  800 USD for a term of 9 months. He is ready to work even harder, make sacrifices and push every once in a while to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur. We believe his perseverance and clear vision will become key success factors in his small business. 
      

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing foodstuffs to increase the range of goods

loans.name: Keo

texts.en:
Keo K. is 47 years old and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. Every day she goes to a sugar cane farm and purchases sugar to re-sell to the market wholesalers. On average, she makes US$ 3 per day. Her husband has been working as a construction worker building houses to supplement the household income. He makes US$ 2 every day.

Keo and her husband have four children, three of whom are in school, while the other is employed as a construction worker. Currently, Mrs. Keo K. is asking for a loan to purchase more sugar cane from the grower.

loans.use: To purchase more sugar cane

loans.name: Phally

texts.en:
Mrs. Phally C., 32, and her husband, Mr. Boun Lay, 34, live along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penn, the capital city of Cambodia. They married in 1995 and have four children: two sons and two daughters. Two of their children are in school and the other two are still too young.

Phally has been selling flowers for fourteen years. She buys them from the villagers in her village for re-sale at market in Phnom Penh. Her husband has been a mason for seventeen years, a skill he learned from his neighbors. The couple also does farming in the village. Phally is requesting a loan of US$ 1000 to use for growing bananas and green beans.

loans.use: To use for growing bananas and green beans

loans.name: Sokhoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhoeun S., 45, and her husband, Mr. Sothorn Soem, 50, who live in a small village across Mekong River about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, married in 1986 and have four children: one son and three daughters. One of their children is a silk weaver and the other children attend school.

Sokhoeun has been a silk weaver for four years, a skill she learned from her sister. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Her husband is a policeman and works in Phnom Penh. Sokhoeun is requesting a loan of 800 USD to purchase a motorbike for her husband to ride to work, using part of the amount for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her husband and supplies for weaving

loans.name: Mrs. Chan Pen Village Bank Group

texts.en:
17 people living in Tropang Pnao village in Kampong Chhnang province and comprise this village bank loan. They will use the loan for a variety of purposes. 

Mrs. Chan P. is a 50 year-old village bank president. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land she uses to cultivate rice. She does not earn enough income to provide a better house for her family. Thus, Mrs. Chan P. has decided to ask for a loan S. that she can potentially build a house for her family to live in. She is a widow with three children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory. 

All the members in this group loan are end-of-term loans S. they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loans term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s client make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To build a house for her family.

loans.name: Marhamat

texts.en:
Marhamat Y.  is 59 years old, married, and has three children. She works purchasing and re-selling cows with her husband. Marhamat is a hard-working woman who has fought to provide for her family and educate her children, who today are working adults thanks to her example. She would like to request a loan of 600 USD for a term of 9 months in order to purchase additional cows to increase her inventory and meet customer demand. She believes this will lead to greater revenue and, ultimately, greater profit for her family. 

In the future, she would like to reinvest the earnings generated by this loan back into her business to purchase additional cows and increase their income further. You could become an important part in Marhamat family's life; she deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving her.

loans.use: Purchasing cattle and calves to expand the business

loans.name: Sean

texts.en:
Sean S., 27, pictured here with her husband, is the mother of three young children and works as a construction worker, building houses in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Every day she earns around US$ 2 to help cover daily expenses. Usually, she stays at home to take care of her children and cook for her family members. Her husband is a fisherman. He catches fish and sells his catch at the market to earn approximately US$ 3 per day.

To make more money, Mrs. Sean is asking for a loan of US$ 500 to purchase a motorbike for her husband. This bike can help her husband get started with a new business as moto-taxi driver. Moreover, they also can use it as transportation to go to their work place.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for transport

loans.name: Arlyn

texts.en:
Arlyn R. is a rice grower. She is 40 years old and has five children. Her life is connected to the soil that she has tilled for many years. Her parents are farmers and they taught her everything about growing rice. Now that she has a family, she would like to increase the profitability of their rice farm.  

She started her business using their 5,059 square metre lot. For many years she has been able to maintain and grow the business. The harvest goes to the family and the remainder is sold to some rice traders in the area to earn additional income. Because of her farm, she has been able to send all her children to school and buy motorcycles for them.

She is asking for a loan from CEVI for her business expansion. She will use the loan to buy Urea fertilizer and other herbicides for her rice farm. In this way, she believes, she will have a bigger harvest. 

CEVI helps Arlyn increase her business. By joining the CEVI program, she is provided with credit assistance, training and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and herbicides.

loans.name: On

texts.en:
Mrs. On K., 66, has three daughters. Two of her daughters are married and live outside the family home and the other one is a tailor. The family lives in a suburb of Phnom Penh, the capita city of Cambodia.

On is a farmer and takes care of her home and her children. The main income in the family is from her daughter’s sewing business. She puts to use a skill she learned from her master. On is asking for her first loan of US$ 500 to purchase a sewing machine for her daughter’s tailoring business.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine for her daughter

loans.name: Kim

texts.en:
Kim K. is 54 years old and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham province. She grows and sells rice from her rice field and earns around US$ 1.50 per day. Her husband owns a plot of land and grows and sells cucumbers to the market. He makes less than one dollar every day. This couple has four children, two of whom are married and two who work as farmers.

Kim K. currently has a new idea to make additional income to help support her family. She is requesting a loan to start raising pigs and purchase more land to expand her cultivation.

loans.use: To raise pigs and purchase land

loans.name: Mutabar

texts.en:
Mutabar Y. is a woman who on a daily basis seeks the betterment of her 3 children. She works with great effort for them and wants to continue to do so to build a prominent and promising future. Ever since she was a little girl, she has been dedicated to farming activities. She was raised this way and it has been a stable source of income until this day.

For more than 11 years, Mutabar together with her husband has been raising sheep and also growing some crops on their land. To continue to work and to obtain a very good quantity and quality, Mutabar wants to borrow money for growing hay and other feed for his sheep on his land. For that she needs to purchase seeds and fertilizer. Let’s show solidarity to this selfless mother who looks for what is best for her children.

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Bunna

texts.en:
Mrs. M. Bunna, 25, and her husband, Mr. Hok Nhean, 32, who live in a small village across Mekong River about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh, married in 2005 and have two children: one son and one daughter, both of whom are still young.

M. has been selling vegetables for two years. She buys them from her villagers for re-sale at the market in Phnom Penh. Her husband has been raising pigs for two years as well. M. is requesting her first loan of US$ 700 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to use as a motor taxi and to transport vegetables to sell.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her husband to drive as a motor taxi and to carry vegetable to sell

loans.name: Rasul

texts.en:
Rasul lives in Kanibadam, the town in Northern Tajikistan. He is 46 years old, married with two children. Rasul is the sole provider for his family and earns his living by raising and selling cows and sheep at the local market. Every year he purchases young animals from local villagers and raises them over an 8-9 month period and later sells the adult cows and sheep to local butchers.

Today Rasul is thinking about expanding his business, as his current earnings are not enough to provide for his family. He plans to purchase young sheep and feed for them. That’s why he is requesting a loan of $1,000 USD for the term of 9 months.

Please extend your solidarity to Rasul so that he can move forth successfully and accomplish all his goals.

loans.use: Purchasing small sheep and feed for them.

loans.name: Mr. Chenda Phat Village Bank Group

texts.en:
13 people who all live in Trapang Buon village in Kampong Chhnang province formed the village bank loan. Mr. Chenda P. is the village bank president. He is a palm juice collector who gathers it to process into palm sugar. Aside from this business, he is a firewood seller in the local village. Since this business is going well, he wishes to expand it buy purchasing a horse in order to transport his firewood to sell door to door. His wife, Mrs. H. Srey Aun, is a palm sugar seller. Mr. Chenda P. is 30 years old and the father of three children, two of whom are attending the local school while the youngest one is too young to work or study because that child is only four years old.

Four members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy a horse in order to transport his firewood to sell door to door.

loans.name: Chanthoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthoeun K., 44, and her husband, Mr. Chhunpov Eang, 52, who live in a small village across Mekong River about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 1985 and have ten children: four sons and six daughters. Three of their children are married and live outside the family home, two sons are security guard, and two daughters are in school.

Chanthoeun sells sickles. She buys them from Kampong Cham province, which is far away from her village, for resale at her house. Her husband has been a policeman for twenty-eight years, and he works in Phnom Penh. Chanthoeun is requesting her first loan to purchase a motorbike to use in her family.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to use in her family.
